title: Patrick Corbin gets lit up as dam finally breaks on Nationals' anti-bullpen strategy
text:
CLOSE

WASHINGTON — The playoffs are a time to push everything – and everyone – to the limit.

The Washington Nationals found out what happens when things get pushed past that in their 10-4 loss Sunday night in Game 3 of the National League Division Series.

With a bullpen that ranked last in the NL with a 5.66 ERA during the regular season, manager Dave Martinez had success in Game 2 bringing in starter Max Scherzer for a scoreless eighth inning as a bridge to closer Daniel Hudson.

The strategy worked to perfection as the Nationals earned a split of the first two games of the series against the Los Angeles Dodgers.

“I don’t think people understand how difficult what Max did the other night really is,” Nationals reliever Sean Doolittle said. “That would be something Max would do – set unrealistic expectations for everybody else.”

SCHERZER: Workhouse gets the ball with Nats' backs against the wall

ALDS: Severino's return gives Yankees a huge boost

As they returned home, the Nationals hoped to get a solid start from Anibal Sanchez, so Martinez could have Game 1 starter Patrick Corbin – who allowed one earned run in six innings three days earlier – come out of the bullpen.

Sanchez did his job, holding the Dodgers to one run in five innings as Washington grabbed a 2-1 lead.

Enter Corbin, who hadn’t pitched in relief since Sept. 29, 2017, as a member of the Arizona Diamondbacks. But this was a playoff game and the Nationals had an opportunity to take control of their series against the 106-win Dodgers.

“We were at a good spot in the lineup where we thought Corbin could get through it,” Martinez said. “And his stuff was good, he’s throwing 94 (mph), slider was good.”

Patrick Corbin reacts during the fateful sixth inning on Sunday. (Photo: Brad Mills, USA TODAY Sports)

The left-hander came close to getting out of the sixth inning unscathed. But two-out, two-run doubles by Russell Martin and Kike Hernandez – both with two strikes – proved to be his undoing as the Dodgers broke the game open.

Corbin said he felt good on the mound, but his slider just didn’t have the break it usually has.

“It’s probably something out of the norm for him, but tip your cap to him,” said catcher Yan Gomes. “These guys take the ball whenever they can. It was the right situation to put him in there.”

Corbin’s final line was rather ugly: Two-thirds of an inning, four hits, two walks, six earned runs.

“We were hoping to get two (innings) out of him, but his limit was going to be about 35 pitches,” Martinez said.

Despite being down 2-1 in the series, the Nationals are still in decent position with Scherzer on the mound in Game 4 on Monday and Stephen Strasburg in line to start a winner-take-all Game 5 in L.A.

But to get there, they’ll probably need to call on Corbin again at some point to help neutralize the Dodgers’ barrage of left-handed hitters – which includes Joc Pederson, Max Muncy, Cody Bellinger and Corey Seager.

During the regular season, Corbin held lefty hitters to a .190/.260/.248 slash line in 137 at-bats. The only other southpaw on the Nationals’ NLDS roster is Doolittle, who generally doesn’t pitch more than an inning at a time.

Corbin wants another chance, so his season doesn’t have to end on such a down note.

“It just stinks,” Corbin said. “I feel like I let these guys down.”

Martinez certainly hasn’t lost confidence in a pitcher the Nationals signed to a six-year, $140 million contract last winter.

“I trust Pat. He’s been unbelievable all year,” Martinez said. “And I would do it again. I really would.

“He looked me in the eye after he came out and says, I’ll be ready tomorrow. So that’s the kind of guys we got on this team.”
description: Coming out of the bullpen, Nationals left-hander Patrick Corbin coughed up a lead in a big way in the sixth inning of Game 4.
